subject: openpower-occ-control:failure to read OCC state.
commitMessage:
openpower-occ-control:failure to read OCC state.

Failure to read OCC state set the OCCs sensors to Nan/Not Functional
Tested: cronus error inject on OCC with and without OCC resets.
Signed-off-by: Sheldon Bailey <baileysh@us.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I2a6bb6a431f09ea816979b3a482b54a28e21db53
Signed-off-by: Sheldon Bailey <baileysh@us.ibm.com>

CI failure due to CLANG formatting required.  Need to run scripts/format-code.sh from the openbmc-build-scripts repo.
You are already in this namespace so these can be removed
Wondering if we need to clear the OCC sensors for each OCC instead of waiting for all of them to go away.
I agree you should clear sensors as each OCC goes away and not wait until they are all gone so we can support if we ever need to just knock out one OCC.
I think you should limit this to only ACTIVE, OBS, CHARACTERIZATION states as those are the only states were the sensors are valid.

This variable is confusing to me.  You are trying to prevent setting the sensors to non functional.  I would prefer to see something like sensorsNonFunctional with same logic.

if (valid state AND sensorsNonFunctional) then 
    // sensors should now be valid
    sensorsNonFunctional = false
You can't clear all OCC sensors here.  This function is called by the Status object for one specific OCC. You would need to know which OCC and only clear sensors for that OCC.

setSensorValuesToNonFunctional

...or have separate methods to set a sensor value to NaN and another to set a sensor to nonfunctional given the sensor path? This would allow more flexibility to do these to sensors individually in the future if needed.

To me you have 2 options.
1) set sensors to Nan.   I have no use case for this, just what was there.
2) set nonFunctional that needs to include setting to Nan so no one uses old data.
Wont this block everything from running for 1s since we're essentially single threaded on the BMC?

It does block occ-control, but if this fails again all of the OCCs will be reset.
It would hold off sensor processing of the other OCCs, which I guess a timer would help, but we only poll every 5 seconds.

if (!good_state && !sensorsNonFunctional) ?

...after saying that, changing `sensorsNonFunctional` to `sensorsFunctional` (or even better to `sensorsValid`) seems more appropriate.
In place until my change for timer is put in.
you could break once you find the match
NO this is going through a list, and when this SENSOR is found for this OCC ID, it will set Nan and NonFunctional, then got to the next one in list.
Maybe add comment that this function is called by Manager to initiate a poll to the OCC.  (to explain how it is different from the occReadStateNow())
Called to read the state (for normal case in addition to when read state fail timer expires)
You can delete this line and just define it on line 342 (could be const) since errno means nothing here
This code could be combined/moved to 395-7 (so you don't have to duplicate same state checks)
There are no retries here.  This is essentially disabling the sensors immediately right?
do you want to set the sensorsValue to true here?  (since they should be good)

You blindly decrement here, but this could be a good or bad read right?
Seems like you would want this after line 433.
Wouldn't we want to set the sensors to not valid as soon as the state is not good?  (since we can't say the data is valid)

I think this block (432-453) could be in #ifdef POWER10.
if the retryCount > 0, it does nothing...
Is that description correct?  Or is the variable saying if the sensors are valid/not

So this really only detecting a failure on "read state"?  What if we get read failure on sensor data, etc?
I guess that might need to be another story?  Matt?
In the case where POWER10 is not defined, sensorsValid is always false (as expected), but it will always go down this leg and eventually trigger deviceError().
This will get called on every retry...  probably fine, but just consumes extra cycles
this is safe to remove because 287 always runs first?
I had moved readOccState() above this call,, which would handle it... and then moved it back, and did not clean up this case.

camelCase is what is recommended.

(I see open_errno also isn't. that was there before so up to you if you want to change that one)
would it be useful to have different traces if it was good_file vs stateValid?  Like on goodfile you could trace the errno and on stateValid you could trace the bad state value
Yes, I can see that being useful.
size_t is usually used to keep track of counts unless there is a reason not to
Instance still not added here, but not a big deal
I did that, must have reverted when I copid to get the ERR,,, I will push that into my next story...
